p: Amusan et al. ( 1996) reported the isolation of antimalarial triterpenoids from the chloroform extract of the stem bark of one of the plants that is tradionally used for the treatment of malaria, Spathodea campanulata (Makinde et al., 1987, 1988a). The triterpenoids, 3β-hydroxyurs-12-en-28-oic acid (ursolic acid; 42) and two of its derivatives, 3β-hydroxyurs-12,19-dien-28-oic acid (tomentosolic acid; 43) and 3β,20 β-dihydroxyurs-12-en-28-oic ( 44) resulted in a significant ( P < 0.05) reduction in parasitaemia and enhanced survival of mice infected with P. berghei. Notably, the effect of 60 mg/Kg/day of 42 on parasitaemia and survival was comparable to 10 mg/Kg/day chloroquine (Amusan et al., 1996).
